Friedrich ⁎ School of Chemistry, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4000, South Africa School of Chemistry, University of KwaZulu-Natal Durban 4000 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +27 31 2603107; fax: +27 31 260 3091. Graphical abstract A non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite (Sr-HAp) was prepared by the co-precipitation method. Vanadium oxide, with loadings of 5, 7.5 and 15wt%, was supported on the strontium hydroxyapatite by the wet impregnation technique. The materials were characterized by techniques such as XRD, in situ XRD, ICP-OES, BET, FTIR, Raman Spectroscopy, SEM, TEM, TPR, TPO, TPD and oxygen chemisorption. From XRD and Raman analyses, vanadium oxide exists in the vanadium pentoxide phase for the 5 and 7.5wt% loadings, whereas an additional pyrovanadate phase appears for the 15wt% loading. Oxidative dehydrogenation reactions were carried out in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. The catalytic results showed that selectivity towards desired products was dependent on the vanadium concentration and the phase composition of the catalyst. Good selectivity towards octenes was achieved using the 5wt% V2O5 catalyst. At a conversion of 24% at 400°C, there was a marked decrease in octene selectivity and a significant increase in the formation of C8 aromatics when V2O5 loading was 15wt%. A maximum selectivity of 12% for C8 aromatics was obtained at a conversion of 32% at 500°C, with the selectivity towards octenes decreasing to 52%. The 5wt% V2O5 on Sr-HAp showed a selectivity of 73% towards octenes and 7% towards aromatics. The higher vanadium loaded catalysts showed preference towards C8 aromatics formation probably due to the pyrovanadate phase present on the surface of the Sr-HAp. Keywords Strontium hydroxyapatite V2O5 n-Octane 1-Octene and o-xylene Oxidative dehydrogenation 1 Introduction A great demand for olefins exists in the chemical industry worldwide [1]. Previously, the commercial production of alkenes from alkanes was carried out in the absence of oxygen. At present, this approach is less appealing since the dehydrogenation of alkanes is a strongly endothermic process. The introduction of oxygen renders the reaction exothermic, eliminates most limitations imposed by thermodynamics and reduces carbon deposits on the catalyst. As a result, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of alkanes would be preferred and should play an increasing role in the petrochemical industry to produce functionalized alkenes [2,3]. The challenge here is preventing the further oxidation of the partially oxidized product to carbon oxides. Catalytic performance relies on the acid–base properties of the material or the isolated cations capable of activating CH bonds [4,5]. Hydroxyapatites (HAp) are bifunctional materials with both acidic and basic sites in the crystal lattice. The general formula of hydroxyapatite (HAp) is [Ca10−x (HPO4) x (PO4)6−x (OH)2−x , 0≤ x ≤1]. Stoichiometric HAp has x =0 to give Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, whereas the calcium deficient non-stoichiometric HAp has 0≤ x ≤1 [6]. HAp have found applications as materials in bioceramics, adsorbents, catalysts and catalyst support materials. It has a hexagonal structure made up from columns of calcium ions and oxygen atoms that are located parallel to the hexagonal axis [7]. Three oxygen atoms from each PO4 tetrahedron are shared by one column and the fourth oxygen atom is attached to the neighbouring column [8]. As a catalyst, HAp was reported to be efficient in the catalytic dehydrogenation of alcohols and the acid catalyzed decomposition of alcohols [9]. The calcium ions in the lattice can be replaced with other cations by ion exchange and ion adsorption or a combination of these methods [7,10,11]. Hydroxyapatites are also efficient as supports, in particular its basic properties are useful for the Knoevenagel reaction in heterogenous media without solvent [12], the water gas shift reaction with gold and ruthenium as the active components and the partial oxidation of methane over nickel-added strontium phosphate incorporating strontium hydroxyapatite [13]. Sr-HAp as support offers high stability and various substitutions are allowed by the apatite structure. The OH group within the phosphate framework of Sr-HAp leads to the formation of active oxygen species which are essential for ODH reactions [6,14,15]. Among the transition metal oxides, supported vanadium oxides find a variety of applications in heterogeneous catalytic oxidation reactions [16,17]. The catalysts consist of a highly dispersed vanadium oxide phase on the surface of the support. There have been very few reports on the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane [18,19]. The effectiveness of vanadium and calcium hydroxyapatite in the ODH of n-octane [20,21] has stimulated our interest leading to the study of the ODH of n-octane using V2O5 supported on Sr-HAp. n-Octane was chosen as a model medium chain length linear paraffin. The supply of these low value linear paraffins is increasing steadily due to the increase in the number of gas – and coal to liquids (GTL and CTL) plants worldwide [22] and annual production already exceed 1 million tonnes per annum. A need exist to valorize these chemicals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts All the chemicals used in the preparation of the catalysts were purchased from Merck KGa, Darmstadt, Germany (99%). The non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite (Sr-HAp) was prepared using the method of Yasukawa et al. [23]. In a typical method for the preparation of Sr-HAp, aqueous NH3 (Merck, 32%) was added to a 60mL solution of Sr(NO3)2·4H2O (6.67×10−2 mol) to elevate the pH to 11. The solution was then diluted to 120mL with distilled water. A 100mL solution of (NH4)2HPO4 (4.00×10−2 mol) was also adjusted to pH 11 and diluted to 160mL. The phosphate solution was added to the calcium solution drop-wise over a period of 30min at room temperature. A gelatinous precipitate formed which was stirred and boiled for 10min. After filtration, the precipitate was washed thoroughly with distilled water and dried in an oven set at 100°C for 12h, thereafter calcined at 550°C. Bulk V2O5 was prepared by the thermal decomposition of NH4VO3 at 450°C for 6h in air. The loading of 5, 7.5 and 15.0wt% vanadia on the Sr-HAp support, which are noted as 5VSr-HAp, 7.5VSr-HAp, 15VSr-HAp respectively, was performed by wet impregnation. The desired amounts of V2O5 were suspended in 20mL of distilled water and added to the Sr-HAp support. The water was removed by evaporation with constant stirring. The solid was dried overnight at 110°C and later calcined at 550°C for 6h. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The BET surface area and pore volume studies were carried out by degassing the catalysts under N2 flow overnight at 200°C using a Micrometrics Flow Prep 060. The degassed samples were analyzed in a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 multi-point BET surface area analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was performed using a Perkin Elmer Optical Emission Spectrometer Optima 5300 DV. Standards (1000ppm Sr, V and P) were purchased from Fluka. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument, equipped with an Anton Paar XRK 900 reaction chamber and a Cu radiation source with a wavelength of 1.5406 λ. The crystallinity of the catalyst was calculated according to the method reported by Kim et al. [24]. In situ XRD diffractograms were obtained at 50°C intervals from 100 to 650°C under 5% hydrogen in nitrogen. The temperature was ramped from 100°C for a 30mL/min hydrogen flow rate. For in situ oxidation air flowed at 20mL/min. Infra-red (IR) spectra were obtained using a Perkin Elmer Precisely equipped with a Universal ATR sampling accessory using a diamond crystal. The powdered sample was placed on the crystal and a force of 120psi was applied to ensure proper contact between the sample and the crystal. Raman spectroscopy was carried out using an Advantage 532 series spectrometer (NIR Spectrometer). Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) were carried out using a Micromeritics 2920 Autochem II Chemisorption Analyser using the method described in [20,25]. The surface morphology of the catalysts was obtained using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) utilizing a Leo 1450 Scanning Electron Microscope. Prior to SEM analysis, the samples were mounted on aluminium stubs using double-sided carbon tape and subsequently gold spluttered using a Polaron E5100 coating unit. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were viewed on a Jeol JEM-1010 electron microscope. The images were captured and analyzed using iTEM software. 2.3 Catalytic testing Gas phase oxidation reactions were carried out in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor in down flow mode. A tubular stainless steel reactor tube with 10mm internal diameter and 300mm length was used to pack the catalyst. The catalyst bed (1mL) was located at the centre of the reactor with 24-grit carborundum packed in the spaces on either side of the bed. The catalyst pellets sizes were between 600 and 1000μm. K-type thermocouples were used to monitor the temperature of the catalyst bed and the reactor furnace. The thermocouples were controlled by CB-100 RK Temperature Control Units. The feed, n-octane (Merck, 99%), was delivered into the system by a high precision isocratic pump (Lab Alliance Series II). The concentration of n-octane in the gaseous mixture was 11% (v/v) with a 1:1 n-octane to oxygen molar ratio. Air (Afrox, 79% N2, 21% O2) was used as an oxidant and nitrogen (Afrox, 98%) was used as the make-up gas to achieve a total flow rate of 90mL/min. The volume of the gaseous products was measured by a wet gas flow meter (Ritter Drum-Type Gas Meter). The gaseous and liquid products were analyzed offline using Perkin Elmer Clarus 400 FID and TCD gas chromotographs. The FID was used for analysis of organic products in both gaseous and liquid phases, whereas the TCD was used for carbon oxides. A Perkin Elmer Clarus 500 GC–MS was used to identify unknown products. Carbon balances ranged between 98 and 100% and all data points were obtained in duplicate with an error of ±1%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Infrared spectroscopy The symmetric ν 1 and asymmetric ν 3 PO stretching modes of the phosphate groups from the strontium hydroxyapatite were observed at 900 and 1200cm−1, as were multiple bands between 900 and 1200cm−1 due to the stretching of both v 1 and v 3 modes of the PO group in the phosphate framework of the strontium hydroxyapatite. The multiple bands are due to the triple degeneration of v 3 in the free ion and resolve into three separate modes when the degeneracy is lifted. Bands in the 500–700cm−1 region are due to the asymmetric PO bending modes of the phosphate groups and peaks at 325cm−1 and 260cm−1 are due to the vibrations of the bond between the metal and the phosphate of the hydroxyapatite [26,27]. Stretching bands observed around 920–1140cm−1 in vanadium oxide supported on strontium hydroxyapatite show the presence of the terminal VO group in V2O5 and a band for the OVO mode of V2O5 is observed at 718cm−1 [28]. The peaks which were observed at around 900–960cm−1 and 700–850cm−1 suggest that the vanadium pentoxide is present as a monolayer on the vanadium oxide supported on strontium hydroxyapatite [29]. In addition to the V2O5 phase, a peak is seen at 666cm−1, which is characteristic of asymmetric stretching of the VOV group in the pyrovanadate phase for 15wt% V2O5 supported on strontium hydroxyapatite. 3.1.2 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra of vanadium oxide supported on strontium hydroxyapatite are shown in Fig. 1 . For Sr-HAp, there are six peaks in the spectral region, three bands for stretching vibrations (in the range from 900 to 1125cm−1) and three bands for bending modes (in the range between 375 and 675cm−1) of PO4 3−. Peaks at 284, 402, 476 and 521cm−1 belong to the V2O5 phase present on the hydroxyapatites and bands between 200–300cm−1 and 500–800cm−1 are assigned to VOV vibrations. The phonon modes in the spectral range below 500cm−1 originate from the bond-bending vibrations, whereas the higher frequency mode is the result of the stretching vibrations of the VO ions. The highest frequency modes at 890, 911 and 986cm−1 represent VO bond stretching vibrations in V2O5. These modes appear at the highest frequencies because they emanate from the shortest distance VO bonds (in the VO5 pyramid and the VO5 octahedron) [30,31]. The Raman mode at 448cm−1 is related to the VOV bending vibration, which appears at a frequency below its intrinsic value, between 470 and 490cm−1 in pure V2O5, meaning that, although there are different site V ions, they are in the mixed valence state (+4.5) [31]. Vanadium is in the +5 state at room temperature and the lines at 996, 703 and 530cm−1 characterize crystalline V2O5. The Raman band observed around 1050cm−1 is assigned to the vibration mode of hydroxyl groups [30]. 3.1.3 Physisorption and chemisorption analysis The elemental composition and surface areas for the catalysts are shown in Tables 1 and 2 . The Sr/P ratio from ICP implied that a non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite was formed [25,26]. The texture of the catalysts was dependent on the V2O5 composition and the higher loading resulted in a significant decrease in the surface area as well as the pore volume. This could be attributed to the blocking of the narrow pores of the support with the active component making it inaccessible to nitrogen molecules [32]. Fig. 2 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for the V2O5 supported on strontium hydroxyapatite catalysts. All the vanadium oxide supported on strontium hydroxyapatite catalysts display the characteristic hysteresis loop of a Type IV isotherm (IUPAC) lying in the p/p° range of 0.6–0.85, demonstrating mesoporous character [33]. All isotherms also show a step increase at a certain relative pressure to the specific pore size in the sample (Table 1). An inflection observed between the p/p° range of 0.85–0.95 may be attributed to the macropores caused by particle–particle porosity, demonstrating that all vanadium oxide supported on strontium hydroxyapatite catalysts have highly ordered regular pore structures. This is also supported by the dispersion of vanandium metal on the surface of the hydroxyapatite. As the vanadium loading increases, the metal dispersion increases (Table 2). The catalysts also exhibit a step increase at this relative pressure range due to the filling of interparticle macropores of the catalyst with the nitrogen [34]. The desorption isotherms support data obtained from nitrogen physisorption that the samples have uniform pore size distribution [35]. 3.1.4 X-ray diffraction The powder XRD diffraction patterns (Fig. 3 ) of all Sr-HAp and the vanadium supported on strontium hydroxyapatite catalysts show the presence of the strontium hydroxyapatite phase with d-spacing values correlating with JCPDS File No. 33-1348 [6,15,30]. The crystallinity of the Sr-HAp was lower (Table 1) when compared to the literature [36], which is due to the formation of non-stoichiometric hydroxyapatite. The unit cell parameters and cell volume of Sr-HAp are also agreement with the literature [37,38]. The presence of V2O5 is also evident in the diffractograms of the loaded catalysts with d-spacing values of 3.43, 2.88 and 2.76Å corresponding to 2θ angles between 30 to 35° referenced in JCPDS File No. 9–387. For the higher vanadium loadings of 15wt%, an additional phase, the pyrovanadate phase was observed with d-spacing values of 3.39, 2.64, 2.51Å. This matches with the data found in JCPDS File No. 25-1103. There was a minimal increase of the crystallite size and crystallinity of the catalysts with an increase in the vanadium loadings for 5 and 7.5wt%. A significant increase in the crystallinity and the crystallite size values of the 15wt% vanadia loadings is observed, probably due to the presence of the pyrovanadate phase (Table 1) [39,40]. For the used catalysts, XRD patterns showed no phase changes. 3.1.5 Temperature programmed reduction and temperature programmed oxidation (TPR-TPO) From analysis (Fig. 4(a)), strontium is not reduced at the temperatures employed, whereas for the supported vanadium pentoxide catalysts, reduction occurs in the 400–800°C range. The reduction process of V2O5 is proposed to be as follows: V2O5 →1/3V6O13 →V2O3 According to Blasco et al. [1,41], the reduction peaks that appear at the higher temperatures correspond with the reduction of V5+ species belonging to the bulk structure of V2O5. The TPR profile (Fig. 4(a) Table 3 ) shows two peaks for the low vanadium loadings (5 and 7.5wt%) indicating that the vanadium exists in one phase and the reduction occurs in two steps. This peak widened and shifted to higher temperatures for the 15wt%. Thus the variations observed in the reduction peak temperature and the line shape may be interpreted as follows: For low vanadium content most of the vanadium atoms interact with the support surface, but as the vanadium increases a higher proportion of surface vanadium atoms interacts with internal vanadium layers. This increases the bond strength of the vanadyl group, approaching eventually that of pure V2O5. This leads to the higher heterogeneity of the vanadium reduction centres which causes the widening of the reduction peak [40,42]. The in situ XRD under a reducing environment (5% H2 in N2) show that vanadium is reduced to the V2O4 (V4+) and V2O3 (V3+) phases (Fig. 5(a)). The d-spacings correlate with the JCPDS File No. 25-1003 for VO4 and JCPDS File No. 26-278 for V2O3 respectively. The Rietvield analysis on the diffractograms shows that the transformation of the V2O5 phase started from 300°C, which correlates with the onset temperature in TPR. Under the reducing environment there is no phase change in Sr-HAp. With increase in temperature, the V2O3 phase increases with decrease in the V2O5 phase (Fig. 6(a)). From 300°C to 400°C, the decrease in the V2O4 phase shows the reduction of pyrovandate (V4+ to V3+). After 400°C, the increase in the V2O4 phases indicates that V5+ is first reduced to V4+. The phase changes in the in situ XRD, peak shapes, along with the hydrogen consumption and the corresponding oxidation states of the reduced vanadium, indicate that vanadium was predominantly reduced to V4+ and that some further reduction to V3+ occurred. In TPR for the higher loadings, the peak between 580 and 620°C is probably due to reduction of the vanadium in slightly different environments, as shown by Rietvield anlaysis of the in situ XRD diffractograms (Fig. 5(a)). The oxidation behaviour of the catalysts and the concentration of oxygen vacancies created by reduction experiments was determined by using temperature programmed oxidation (TPO). During TPO, the catalysts are pretreated in order to avoid structural changes. In the TPR experiment the temperature ramping was stopped at 950°C and the temperature was maintained until the hydrogen consumption reached the base line. There was no phase transition of the Sr-HAp during this treatment which was corroborated by XRD. Once the catalyst was cooled to room temperature under Ar, a TPO experiment was conducted [43]. The oxidation temperature in all TPO profiles was 400°C, hence oxidation occurs at a lower temperature compared to reduction. The TPO profiles exhibit two separate peaks, representing a two step oxidation process in the formation of V2O5 (Fig. 4(b)). The TPO profile resembles the envelope of the TPR profile viewed from higher to lower temperatures. This suggests that the transitions observed in the TPR experiments with V2O5 are reversed in the TPO experiments [43]. Two steps can be distinguished according to the integrated oxygen consumption, the first peak at around 400–600°C corresponds the transition of V2O3 to V2O4, and the second sharp peak at around 600–800°C represents the formation of V2O5. V2O3 →⅓V6O13/V2O4 →V2O5 Compared to unsupported V2O5, supported vanadia catalysts are easier to reduce and re-oxidize. These results suggest that polymeric and crystalline vanadia species present at higher vanadium loadings are easiest to re-oxidize but difficult to reduce, whereas highly dispersed vanadia present at lower vanadium loadings are easier to reduce but more difficult to re-oxidize (Table 4 ). This is in agreement with the results obtained by Majunke et al. [44] who observed a higher degree of reduction for lower vanadium loadings at the same conditions. The peak shapes along with the oxygen consumption and the corresponding oxidation states of the oxidized vanadium indicate that vanadium was predominantly oxidized to V4+ and further oxidation to V5+ occurred (Table 4). This is also supported by Rietvield analysis of the in situ XRD diffractograms obtained under an oxidation environment (air). In situ XRD studies under air show that V2O3 (V3+) is oxidized to the V2O4 (V4+) and V2O5 (V5+) phases (Fig. 5(b)). The d-spacings correlate with the JCPDS File Nos. 25-1003 and 9-378 for V2O5 and V2O4 respectively. The transformation of V2O3 to V2O5 is complete as the oxidation of vanadium oxide occurs at lower temperatures than reduction (Fig. 6(b)). As the vanadium content is increased, in TPO the peak at the lower temperature gradually increases in area, and the peak at higher temperature progressively diminishes. The shift of the peak temperatures for the lower vanadium loadings indicates that the oxidation of the corresponding vanadium species in the catalyst becomes difficult. 3.1.6 Temperature programmed desorption From the TPD experiments (Table 5 ), each catalyst exhibits weak and strong acidic sites shown by the peaks at 480°C and 690°C respectively. There is a direct correlation in the magnitudes of the weak and strong acidic sites with respect to vanadium pentoxide loadings. The weak acidic sites increase gradually until a loading of 7.5wt% V2O5 is reached and decrease for the higher loadings (Table 5). On the other hand, the strong acidic nature of the catalysts increases for the higher loadings due to the presence of the strongly acidic pyrovanadate phase. Acidic sites in the used catalyst are marginally decreased; this is probably due to the blocking of acidic sites by hydrocarbon molecules. 3.1.7 Scanning and transmission electron microscopy SEM micrographs (Fig. 7 ) show the rough surface morphologies of the strontium hydroxyapatite crystals, and from SEM-EDX data the homogenous dispersion of vanadium pentoxide on the surface can be observed. From the SEM micrographs, the Sr-HAp appears as a polycrystalline material. For the 5wt% V2O5 supported on Sr-HAp, the V2O5 is uniformly distributed as small crystals on the surface. However, for the 7.5wt% loadings, plate like structures are observed and these materials are more crystalline. Micrographs of the 15wt% supported catalyst show distorted plate like structures. EDX data also show a calcium to phosphorus ratio of 1.67 which correlates with the value from ICP (Table 1). TEM micrographs (Fig. 8 ) show that the vanadium supported on Sr-HAp particles are rod-like in shape with sizes varying from 150 to 180nm. The SADP diffraction patterns for catalysts with lower loadings show that the crystals are polycrystalline, whereas for the 15wt% loadings, diffractions spots along the concentric circles show the crystalline nature of the catalysts. The hydroxyapatite exists as clustered micro rod-like particles but as the vanadium loading increases, the micro rod-like particles become more defined. For the used catalysts, there is no drastic change in the morphology of the catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic testing Catalytic testing was carried out in a fixed bed continuous flow reactor over a temperature range of 350–550°C with the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) initially fixed at 4000h−1. Low conversion of n-octane was obtained over Sr-HAp compared to the supported vanadium pentoxide catalysts. All the supported catalysts showed an increase in conversion of n-octane with an increase in temperature as expected (Fig. 9 ). At temperatures between 350°C and 400°C, moderate conversions (20–30%) were recorded due to the dominance of the vanadium pentoxide phase, where V5+ is found in an octahedral environment with terminal VO bonds, resulting in incorporation of oxygen in the intermediate reaction products [45]. An increase in the oxygen conversion over the temperature range resulted in an increase in the formation of carbon oxides (Fig. 9). 3.2.1 Product selectivity A range of octenes and C8 aromatics, cracked products and carbon oxides (CO x ) were present in the product stream. Cracked products included mainly butane, propane and ethane. Oxygenates included C8 oxygenates (octanal, 2-octanal and 3-octanal) and lower oxygenates (acetone, acetic acid, butanol and propanol). Octenes were the major products for all the catalysts. The selectivity towards octenes for low loadings (5wt% and 7.5wt%) decreased as the catalyst loadings and temperature increased due to the increased formation of aromatics, cracked products and CO x . Selectivity towards octenes increased with loading from 7.5wt% to 15wt%. (Fig. 10 ). This is explained by the presence of vanadium pyrophosphate which favours the formation of alkenes from alkanes, since the octane adsorbed on the catalyst is activated by the highly reactive surface oxygen species in the isolated tetrahedral VO4 which abstracts a hydrogen atom from the hydrocarbon molecule to form an adsorbed alkyl radical and a surface OH group [45]. The possible synergistic co-existence between the V2O5 and the pyrovanadate phases could also enhance the rapid desorption of the formed octenes from the catalyst surface and thereby increase their selectivity [20,29]. The high selectivity towards aromatics and low selectivity for CO x shown by the 15wt% loaded catalyst is attributed to the stable aromatic nucleus in o-xylene, representing a driving force for the formation of these compounds and thereby reducing the production of carbon oxides, including the contribution from secondary combustion [41]. An opposite trend is shown for cracked products. As the vanadium content increases, cracked product selectivity decreases (Fig. 10). 3.2.2 Product selectivity at iso-conversion Product selectivity at iso-conversion for the prepared catalysts was compared at 400°C (21% conversion of n-octane) and 500°C (32% conversion of n-octane) (Fig. 11a and b). In both cases, octene selectivity decreases gradually with an increase in vanadium loading. There was an increased appearance of aromatics as the vanadium concentration increased and this opposite trend to that exhibited by the octenes suggests that octenes are aromatics precursors. For the 15wt% loading, the relatively slow desorption of the basic octenes from the catalyst surface lowers their selectivity, but simultaneously causes aromatic selectivity to increase by allowing the formed octenes to be oxidized further to give the corresponding aromatics (Fig. 11c and d). The desorption of products is dependent on the acid–base character of the catalyst. The selectivites of octenes at iso-conversion correlates well with both acidic and basic character of the catalysts. The selectivity towards octenes is dependent on the vanadium concentration and the type of the secondary phase present in the catalyst. The 5wt% loading gives good selectivity towards 1-octene, and this decreases slightly with an increase in vanadium concentration. The cis- and trans-2-octenes are the dominant products among all the octenes. The selectivity to trans-2-octene is found to be higher than cis-2-octene due to the relative thermodynamic stability of trans-isomers compared to the respective cis-isomers [46,47] (Fig. 11c and d). There is low selectivity towards 4-octene, although there is no difference in the energies of the CH bond at C2, C3 and C4 in the alkane chain [48]. Hodnett et al. [47] proposed a mechanism for alkane activation where they suggested that the rate determining step is the homolytic breaking of CH bonds from the surface alkyl species with the catalyst, followed by a fast elimination of second hydrogen from a neighbouring carbon to form the olefinic bond. A different study on the activation of n-octane, suggested that steric effects are likely to play a vital role in the accessibility to active sites by large molecules and this is likely to become a limiting factor [2,32,49]. In general, the aromatics are formed by the cyclization via C1 to C6 and C2 to C7 bonding. In a separate experiment, 1,7 Octadiene was fed over the catalysts with low vanadium loadings (5 and 7.5wt%), and the cyclization was found to have taken place predominantly through the C1 to C6 mode: over the 5wt% loaded catalyst, more than 75% of the cyclization follows this mode at lower temperatures. The modes of cyclization were further studied by feeding octenes, i.e. 1-octene, 2-octene, 3-octene and 4-octene at a GHSV 4000h−1, with a 1:1 n-octane to oxygen molar ratio. 1-Octene is preferentially consumed during the C1 to C6 cyclization and this eventually leads to the formation of ethyl benzene and styrene. 1-Octene and 1,7 octadiene can provide 6 sequential sp3 carbon atoms for this type of cyclization. The sp3 carbons, unlike the sp2 carbons, possess free rotation along the bond axis and hence the flexibility needed for the ring formation [17]. The tendency towards the C2 to C7 cyclization of octane generally increases as the temperature increases, presumably because raising the temperature will provide more energy to overcome any activation barrier. The higher vanadium loadings (15wt%) showed the highest tendency (>90%) towards the C2 to C7 cyclization at 500°C, while the 5wt% loaded catalyst exhibited the lowest tendency to this mode, especially at high temperatures (Fig. 11e and f). Feeding the octenes showed that 2-octene, 3-octene and 4-octene are preferentially consumed during C2 to C7 cyclization and eventually leads to the formation of o-xylene. The C2 to C7 cyclization mechanism thus dominates over the C1 to C6 mechanism seen over VMgO catalysts [17,19]. The 15wt% loading showed a higher selectivity towards C8 aromatics compared to carbon dioxides, indicating that aromatic formation provides an energetically favourable pathway, thus lowering CO x formation. Here, o-xylene selectivity is far greater than that of styrene and ethyl benzene. Cracked products also decrease with increasing vanadium loading, although the selectivity to these products are low. 3.2.3 Yields of 1-octene and o-xylene Among all the catalysts, 5% V-HAp showed the highest selectivity and yield towards 1-octene. This can be explained by the ease at which this catalyst is reduced at a lower temperature, compared to the other catalysts. At temperatures above 450°C, catalysts with low vanadium loadings showed high yields towards 1-octene, but this decreased with an increase in vanadium concentration, since octenes are converted to aromatics and oxygenates at the higher temperatures. For o-xylene formation, the 15wt% loading showed good yields at 400°C and 500°C (Fig. 11e and f). At low temperatures, all catalysts showed low selectivity towards aromatics and low yields of o-xylene were obtained because the dominant V2O5 phase favours the formation of oxygenates instead of alkenes and aromatics. This is confirmed by the presence of oxygenates as by-products and high selectivities towards CO x [44,50,51]. 4 Conclusion All the characterization techniques showed that vanadium oxide is supported in the form of vanadium pentoxide on non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite. For the 15wt% loading, vanadium exhibits two types of phases, the vanadium pentoxide and pyrovanadate phase, confirmed by XRD diffractograms and supported by Raman spectroscopy. TPR profiles showed that as the vanadium concentration increases, reduction occurs at higher temperatures. TPD showed that total acidity of the catalysts is proportional to the vanadium loading present on the surface of the catalysts. Oxidative dehydrogenation experiments showed that vanadium pentoxide, which is the dominant phase in the lower loadings, gave high selectivity towards octenes and low selectivity towards aromatics. All the catalyst showed moderate to high selectivity towards carbon oxides, since vanadium pentoxide also favours the formation of oxygenates which ultimately give carbon oxides. The C2 to C7 cyclization mode is the favourable mode for formation of aromatics [52] and aromatics selectivity increases with both vanadium content and temperature. At a 15wt% vanadium oxide loading, a significant selectivity towards aromatics was obtained compared to the other catalysts although octenes were the major products, which is due to the presence of the pyrovanadate phase. There is no significant change in the structure and morphology of the used catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite (Sr-HAp) was prepared by the co-precipitation method. Vanadium oxide, with loadings of 5, 7.5 and 15wt%, was supported on the strontium hydroxyapatite by the wet impregnation technique. The materials were characterized by techniques such as XRD, in situ XRD, ICP-OES, BET, FTIR, Raman Spectroscopy, SEM, TEM, TPR, TPO, TPD and oxygen chemisorption. From XRD and Raman analyses, vanadium oxide exists in the vanadium pentoxide phase for the 5 and 7.5wt% loadings, whereas an additional pyrovanadate phase appears for the 15wt% loading. Oxidative dehydrogenation reactions were carried out in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. The catalytic results showed that selectivity towards desired products was dependent on the vanadium concentration and the phase composition of the catalyst. Good selectivity towards octenes was achieved using the 5wt% V2O5 catalyst. At a conversion of 24% at 400°C, there was a marked decrease in octene selectivity and a significant increase in the formation of C8 aromatics when V2O5 loading was 15wt%. A maximum selectivity of 12% for C8 aromatics was obtained at a conversion of 32% at 500°C, with the selectivity towards octenes decreasing to 52%. The 5wt% V2O5 on Sr-HAp showed a selectivity of 73% towards octenes and 7% towards aromatics. The higher vanadium loaded catalysts showed preference towards C8 aromatics formation probably due to the pyrovanadate phase present on the surface of the Sr-HAp.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium oxide supported on non-stoichiometric strontium hydroxyapatite catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane
